Up beam configuration was assumed to illuminate a Au NP supported on the top wall (ceiling) of the sample chamber. (b) Calculated particle temperature as a function of applied laser peak power density for water-immersed 100-nm-Au NP on sapphire (red line) and glass (black line) substrates. (c) Calculated 1D temperature profiles along upper (z=0) and lower (z=−100 nm) sides of the particle (100 nm in diameter), showing that a Au NP supported on sapphire substrate is cooler on the upper side (laser peak power density: 5.3 mW μm−2). (d) Schematic illustrating plasmonic-heating-induced Marangoni convective flow. (e) The 2D temperature distribution and the emerging free convective flow (white arrows) from optical heating of a 100-nm diameter Au NP (simulation). The particle temperature was set to 500 K that generated a flow velocity of 2.4 nm s−1 in front of the Au NP. Note that 1.0 mW μm−2=105 W cm−2=109 W m−2. Reprinted from Aibara et al.70 (f) Time-dependent LSPR red shifts with enhanced scattering spectral intensities for a single 100-nm-diameter Au NP at 4-s irradiation intervals for 5.0% PEG 6000 solution on a sapphire substrate. SEM images of (g) a bare Au NP and (h) a Au NP irradiated in the presence of 5.0% PEG. The shells were formed with 10 illumination cycles of 4 s (total 40 s) and a laser peak power density of 8.8 mW μm−2. Reprinted from Enders et al.81.

From the viewpoint of single-particle heating, we examine the recent observation of plasmonic-heating-induced fabrication by Enders et al.81 They used a 100-nm-diameter single Au NP supported on sapphire (2D temperature profile: Figure 18a, right) as a platform for the formation of NSs. They observed the transport of molecules such as polyethylene glycol (molecular weight of 6000 g mol−1, abbreviated PEG 6000) and sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) toward the Au NP, which then attached to its surface. They formed a gold core–organic shell structure within several tens of seconds after illumination by a 488-nm laser, which raised the particle temperature to ~360–400 K. Spectroscopically, because of the gradual increase in encapsulation, progressive redshifts with enhanced scattering intensities are seen in the LSPR bands of the Au NP with increasing illumination cycles (Figure 18f). Post-mortem SEM provided direct evidence of shell formation (compare the before and after images in Figures 18g and h). The observation of nanoscale heating-induced accumulation of polymers around the NP was unexpected due to the presumption that the experimental laser intensities of <106 W cm−2 were insufficient for the optical trapping of such molecules without plasmonic substrates. Alternatively, the optical-heating-induced Marangoni and thermal convections were considered likely to cause molecules to be carried toward the particle.

The observation that single Au NP heating induced the fabrication of core-shell structures prompted a study of thermoresponsive polymers to promote phase transition/phase separation for heating at the nanoscale.71 Such possibility was tested with poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAM), which is a well-investigated water-soluble thermoresponsive polymer.82 At room temperature, PNIPAM dissolves in water in a random coil state forming a homogeneous phase; when heated to temperatures above 32 °C (305 K)—the lower critical solution temperature (LCST)—a phase transition occurs from a coil to a globule state. The globular molecules aggregate due to hydrophobic interactions, resulting in phase separation and causing the solution to turn turbid. Previously, microscopy observations revealed that the phase transition of PNIPAM resulted in microparticle formation when aqueous solutions were heated directly with a focused infrared laser.83, 84 This was also observed in D2O, for which the absorption of infrared light is negligible; the PNIPAM formed microparticles in response to the optical force.83, 84

Figure 19a shows the single-particle Rayleigh scattering spectral changes originating from the heating of a Au NP in 1.0% aqueous PNIPAM solution. At a laser peak power density of 1.8 × 104 W cm−2 (0.18 mW μm−2), the spectral shift was within experimental error, whereas appreciable redshifts at 3.5 × 104 W cm−2 and 5.3 × 104 W cm−2 were recorded. Notably, these shifts occurred only during illumination; when stopped, the original spectra returned. For plasmon-assisted optical trapping, although not a heating effect, the reversible aggregation of PNIPAM on a Au NS substrate, forming microparticles, was observed microscopically at intensities as low as ~103 W cm−2.85Figure 19
(a) In situ scattering spectral changes: before, during, and after laser illumination of a 100-nm-diameter Au NP supported on a glass substrate and submerged in aqueous solution of 1.0% PNIPAM. (b, c) Scattering spectra during the illumination of 488-nm laser light at laser peak power densities, 0.18, 0.35 and 0.53 mW μm−2, together with spectra before and after irradiation. Right panel: single-particle scattering spectrum with corresponding SEM image (inset) of (b) pristine Au NP and (c) subsequent changes arising from laser illumination after irradiation at 5.3 mW μm−2 for 8 s. Reprinted from Aibara et al.71.

The origin of the spectral shifts in the PNIPAM/Au NP system is ascribed to an increase in the refractive index sensed by the Au NP.86 The phenomenon was interpreted as the LCST-induced aggregation of PNIPAM around the NP due to heating of the surrounding medium by heat transfer from the optically heated NP. PNIPAM molecules are hydrophilic at temperatures below the LCST (305 K) but hydrophobic above the LCST.82 The phase transition and aggregation of PNIPAM may increase the refractive index of the medium sensed by the Au NP, resulting in LSPR redshifts. Remarkably, the reversible spectral changes observed at low laser intensities became irreversible when the laser intensity exceeded the specified limit (2.6 × 105 W cm−2 on a sapphire substrate). As a result, shell formation occurred around the Au NP, as evidenced in the SEM images, which is consistent with the permanent scattering spectral redshift (Figures 19b and c). Polymer-shell formation around the Au NP can be regarded as due to liquid–liquid phase separation and accumulation. This phenomenon is intriguing because accumulation occurs around the hot NP. The advantage of single plasmonic NP heating-induced fabrication is that in situ spectroscopic monitoring of the reaction is feasible before SEM analysis.

Single plasmonic NP heating-induced glass structuring was implemented by Osaka and coworkers.87 They demonstrated the fabrication of nanoholes on glass surfaces by embedding Au NPs under photoillumination. As illustrated in Figure 20 (left), single Au NPs supported on a borosilicate glass substrate submerged in aqueous alkaline solution, such as tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH), were subjected to illumination with a focused laser beam that excites the LSPR band of the NPs. The SEM images (Figures 20a–f, center) exhibit the effect of laser exposure on the glass surfaces. Before illumination (Figure 20a), the particle is supported on the glass surface; after illumination for 10 s, the Au sphere sinks into the substrate, fitting just inside a cavity (Figure 20b). By increasing the irradiation period to 30 s (Figure 20c) or 30 min (Figure 20d), deeper holes are fabricated; the particle is seen in Figure 20c but not in Figure 20d. When a Au nanotriangle was used instead of a Au nanosphere, a nanohole with a triangular face was fabricated (Figure 20e). However, when illuminated at a lower laser intensity of 1.7 mW μm−2—one half of that used in this instance (Figure 20f)—the Au nanotriangle remains on the glass surface without forming a nanohole. This suggests that a threshold intensity exists for nanohole fabrication. On silica glass, nanoholes were fabricated in the same manner as for borosilicate glass.Figure 20
Left: experimental outline for plasmonic-heating-induced nanohole fabrication on glass substrates. Center: SEM images showing the laser-induced embedding into glass substrate for illumination with a peak power density of 5.0 mW μm−2 on 100-nm-diameter Au nanospheres (a–d) and Au nanotriangles (e, f). (a) before irradiation, Au NP is sitting on the substrate surface; (b) after 10 s of irradiation, Au NP is fallen into a hole; (c), after 30 s of irradiation, Au NP is seen at the bottom; (d), after 30 min of irradiation, Au NP is far inside the hole and could not be seen. (e) after irradiation at 180 s at 3.3 mW μm−2, Au nanotriangle is embedded; (f) after irradiation for 180 s at 1.7 mW μm−2, no embedding of Au nanotriangle is seen. All scale bars represent 100 nm. Right: dark-field optical microscope images (upper panels) and corresponding cross-sectional schematics (lower panels) of the steps used to create a horizontal nanohole by manipulating a Au NP using the laser focus spot. First, a Au NP, orange spot at the center of (g) supported on a glass substrate was embedded with focused laser illumination of intensity 3.3 mW μm−2 for 40 min. After embedding, the laser focusing spot was moved horizontally in small steps; after 120 min (h), we see the Au NP is 2 μm from the nanohole entrance (circled). The scale bars represent 2 μm. Reprinted with permission from Osaka et al.87 (Copyright 2016, The Royal Society of Chemistry).

The susceptibility to etching of the glass surface is ascribed to laser-heating-induced structural modification because heat transfer from the particle causes the temperature of the glass surface to increase. The steady-state particle temperatures reached were estimated to be 400−500 K. During the alkali etching of glass, [OH−] plays a crucial role for facile processing. In this regard, the ion product of water, Kw is temperature-dependent. As the temperature increases from 298 K to 400 and 500 K, Kw increases from 10−14.0 to 10−11.9 and 10−11.2.79 The resulting higher [OH−] should markedly increase the etching rate of glass.

To embed the particle forcefully and fabricate nanoholes in desired directions, an optical manipulation technique was applied (Figures 20g and h). First, a Au NP (orange spot at the center) supported on a glass substrate (Figure 20a) was illuminated, and the particle was embedded. Then, the focal spot of the laser beam (d=~1 μm) was moved near the embedded particle to shift it laterally in the direction the focal spot is moving, to a distance ~2 μm from the entrance after 120 min of illumination (Figure 20b). Presumably, the scattering force from the laser beam pushes the particle.88 Using diffraction-limited optics and a piezo stage would improve this form of manipulation.

Aside from this etching-assisted nanohole fabrication using an embedded Au NP, mere homogeneous heating in an oven embeds Au NPs into SiO2 glass. Au particles with an initial diameter of 1 μm and thickness of 18 nm were buried into SiO2 glass when heated to 1050 °C, leaving nanoholes, as reported by de Vreede et al.89 After 9 hours of heating, a 0.8-μm-deep nanohole was formed, reducing the Au NP diameter to 25 nm. Evaporation of the Au NP occurs during the process as the temperature was close to the melting point of Au (1064 °C). The driving force in the embedding is the continual evaporation of Au transporting SiO2 to the surface, which led to ridge formation. In practice, their method is hindered by its slowness, unfavorable ridge deposits and the channel narrowing with depth. For nanohole fabrication, etching is free from these shortcomings. Interestingly, Hidai and coworkers90 used a system similar to that of de Vreede and coworkers but instead illuminated the glass substrate with a CW laser (λ=514 nm) horizontally from the opposite side, such that the migration of metal microparticles occurs but no holes are produced. In this instance, a liquid droplet of the metal moves within the glass toward the laser direction, softening the glass ahead of the moving particle. The void created behind the particle is filled by the softened glass and rapidly cooled at ambient temperature. The result suggests that etching reagents are essential for glass structuring. Furthermore, plasmonic heating combined with etching reagents is useful for triggering and terminating fabrication as well as controlling the etching rate using light.

sec.title: Plasmonic field enhancement-based fabrication
sec.p: Energy-saving plasmonic enhancement has been applied for two-photon and multi-photon-mediated photochemistry:62 photoisomerization, photopolymerization and photomodification. Here we give examples of unconventional structuring achieved through multi-photon processes.

On DNA nanowires prepared on a poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) film, plasmon-mediated excitation transfer over one micron was demonstrated with Au NPs attached to a double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) excited using a femtosecond laser pulse.91 AFM images (Figure 21, upper left frames) show the effects of the femtosecond laser pulses at λ=1030 nm, clearly indicating that only the parallel alignment of the excitation electric field is effecting long-range changes. Upon illumination using diagonally polarized laser pulses, only local damage was seen (Figures 21a and b). By contrast, extensive damage was observed in the DNA strand when illuminated by vertical/horizontally polarized pulses (Figures 21c and d). Underlying this observation is the plasmonic excitation-induced escape of electrons, which damages the DNA strand and the PMMA support as well as embeds the Au NPs into the film. These plasmonic excitation-induced events observed using femtosecond lasers were categorized into three groups: (1) LSPR excitation; (2) single Au NP exaction-induced electron emission into the host PMMA and damage; and (3) excitation transfer from Au NP multimers (dimers, trimers) to DNA, resulting in extensive damage (Figure 21, upper right frames). In explaining the observed ablation, photothermal effects were eliminated based on temperature calculations giving a rise of only 40 K at most, as this temperature is too low to embed a metal NP in a PMMA layer compared with the required temperature of 300 K. Their main point is that the plasmon-enhanced strong electric field can drive NP electron tunneling based on four-photon excitation using a laser wavelength of 1030 nm (1.20 eV) to overcome the work function of gold (~5.5 eV).Figure 21
Upper left: AFM images showing the effects of electric field alignment (with respect to the long axis of nanoparticle multimers) on excitation transfer along DNA (height scale: 15 nm). For diagonal polarization, only local damage along the DNA is observed (~200-nm fragmentation); only the particle is present before irradiation (a) and disappears into the substrate (b). When the field is aligned (horizontal polarization) (c), irradiation results also in extensive damage (~2-μm fragmentation) along the DNA (d). Upper right: Schematics showing three steps of excitation during femtosecond laser irradiation of metallic nanoparticles associated with surface phenomena and their effects on surroundings. Reprinted with permission from Wirth et al.91 (Copyright 2014, American Chemical Society). Lower frame: Polarized femtosecond laser(λ=800 nm, 120 fs)-mediated growth and programmable assembly of photoreduced silver nanoparticles into triply hierarchical micropatterns (thickness ~30 nm): (i) the excited surface plasmons enhance the local electric field and lead to spatially selective growth of silver atoms at the opposite ends of dipoles induced on early created silver seeds; (ii, iii) the optical attractive force overcomes electrostatic repulsion in the enhanced local electric field to assemble the silver nanoparticles directly. Reprinted with permission from Xu et al.92 (Copyright 2014, American Chemical Society).

Another example is the multi-photon-induced optical fabrication of hierarchically integrated metal NSs employing silver. In this research, the femtosecond-laser mediated growth and assembly of photoreduced Ag NPs into nanoplates and micropatterns were revealed (Figure 21, lower frame).92 First, the photoreduction of silver ions in solution in the presence of ammonia and trisodium citrate occurs through the multi-photon absorption of a 800-nm laser to form Ag NPs. Then, the LSPR fields were excited and established on the Ag seeds (far left), launching directional growth along the dipole ends by attracting atoms that were photoreduced in solution (i). Finally, nanoplates formed gradually (ii and iii), resulting in an arrayed structure (far right).

Thus, the production of nanoplate arrays was attributed to the local field enhancement induced by the LSPR mode of the Ag particles. One can eliminate the potential involvement of the ripple mechanism,93 that is, the periodic structures created by light interference, either between incident laser beams or between the incident beam and its excited waves. In the ripple formation, the patterns replicate the light intensity redistributions, and the structure periods depend on the laser wavelength and the beam incident angles.

sec.title: Conclusion and future outlook
sec.p: To date, the power conversion efficiency of plasmonic solar cells is still less than 1%, which is much lower than that achieved by current commercial solar cells (~20%), such as crystalline silicon cells. Plasmonic solar cells, however, have many attractive features, given that they can operate as a very thin film because of their very strong and widely tunable photoabsorption in the visible and NIR wavelength regions. Ultrafast spectroscopy has revealed that hot-electron transfer from plasmon-excited Au to a contacting semiconductor occurs within 100 fs, and the efficiency is between 20 and 80%. Hot spots generated through electric-field enhancements at specific positions in an Au NS potentially play an important role in hot-electron generation. If hot electrons approach the electron-accepting semiconductor, the transfer is efficient even in the presence of an intervening insulator barrier. Such an insulator layer or Schottky barrier in a semiconductor can suppress the unfavorable back electron transfer, increasing the photovoltage. Precise control over gold-interface semiconductor NSs would significantly increase the performance of future plasmonic solar cells.

Plasmonic photocatalysts will also continue to be an attractive research target because of their unique properties. Gold NSs on TiO2 are well recognized to be good photoanodes to produce O2 through the water-splitting reaction. H2 can also be produced in the presence of a Pt cocatalyst on TiO2. Their combination would enable a photocatalytic electrochemical sheet to split water into H2 and O2. As gold has a strong absorption, even small amounts can induce a sufficient visible-to-NIR response in conventional TiO2 catalysts to be used for environmental purification in hospitals or public buildings.94 To improve the efficiency of plasmonic solar cells and photocatalysts, it is very important to understand the primary processes in the reactions. With powerful femtosecond time-resolved and nanometer space-resolved spectroscopic techniques, further advancements may accelerate the development of plasmonic devices and materials. Ultrasmall photodetectors, optical switches for information technology95 and photocatalysts for cancer therapy96 would then emerge as new applications.

With optically driven nanofabrication taking advantage of plasmonic NPs and NSs, two approaches are being developed to avoid mixing photothermal effects and optical manipulation. To pursue pure optical trapping free from photothermal effects, Au NSs were fabricated on a Au film, which acted as an effective heat sink because of its large thermal conductivity (314 W m−1 K−1) while reflecting most of the incident laser light.97 Further improvements in suppressing heating can be achieved by using a film or substrate made of diamond, which has a thermal conductivity of 1000 W m−1 K−1. Another way of quenching thermal convection resulting from medium water heating is to maintain the temperature at ~4°C; with a vanishingly small thermal expansion coefficient, buoyancy forces are thereby suppressed.98 If thermal convection is minimized in plasmon-assisted trapping, the area of trapping is significantly reduced, leading to assemblies of much smaller scale. Photothermal trapping to form assemblies similar to those prepared by optical forces is unexpected but intriguing for less refined protocols. Still, the details of the driving mechanism are poorly understood. In particular, the details of thermophoresis, such as the direction of thermodiffusion, is not well understood.99 Further theoretical treatment of photothermal trapping is needed.

Nevertheless, plasmonic heating has found useful applications. For instance, single-particle heating can be effective for metal core-polymer shell fabrication and glass structuring. In addition, plasmonic heating-induced crystallization on Au NP assemblies is promising for the hydrothermal synthesis of various nanocrystals at atmospheric pressure. These new methods should be pursued with further sophistication. Nanofabrication techniques that fully exploit the plasmonic properties are advancing the field of optical manipulation-based materials science and technology, and we expect to see steady development over the next few years.
Concept of plasmon-enhanced optical trapping vs. conventional optical trapping. (Left) Optical trapping of a NP at the focal point of the laser beam. (Center) Scattering force that pushes the particle against the wall. (Right) plasmonic optical tweezers that can trap at the plasmonic active nanospace with significantly reduced laser powers.
Concept of thermophoretic trapping from central heating originating from an interplay of lateral thermophoresis (1), (4) and axial thermophoresis (3) with convection (2). Reprinted with permission from Braun and Libchaber58 (Copyright 2002, American Institute of Physics).
